headline: Molecular cloud discovered surprisingly close to Earth, scientists say | CNN
context: The molecular cloud was detected 300 light-years from Earth, closer than any other similar, star-forming clouds.

annotations.paragraph:

annotations.reason: This is a formatting element and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: An invisible molecular cloud that could shed light on how stars and planets form has been detected surprisingly close to Earth.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the discovery of the molecular cloud, which is central to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: Named Eos after the Greek goddess of the dawn, the cloud of gas would appear huge in the night sky if visible to the naked eye. It measures roughly 40 moons in width and has a weight about 3,400 times the mass of the sun, researchers reported in a study published Monday in the journal Nature Astronomy.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the molecular cloud, including its name, size, and mass, which are relevant to the article's main story.

annotations.paragraph: “In astronomy, seeing the previously unseen usually means peering deeper with ever more sensitive telescopes — detecting those smaller planets … those more distant galaxies,” said study coauthor Thomas Haworth, an astrophysicist at Queen Mary University of London.
annotations.reason: This quote provides context on the significance of the discovery in the field of astronomy, contributing to the article's narrative.

annotations.paragraph: “This thing was pretty much in our cosmic backyard, and we’ve just missed it,” he added.
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes the surprising proximity of the molecular cloud, which is central to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: Molecular clouds are composed of gas and dust from which hydrogen and carbon monoxide molecules can form. Dense clumps within these clouds can collapse to form young stars.
annotations.reason: This provides essential context about what molecular clouds are and their role in star formation.

annotations.paragraph: Scientists usually spot a molecular cloud using radio and infrared observations that can pick up the chemical signature for carbon monoxide, Haworth explained.
annotations.reason: This explains the typical method for detecting molecular clouds, relevant to understanding the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: “We normally look for carbon monoxide, just one carbon atom and one oxygen atom, and that emits light pretty easily at wavelengths that we can detect,” he said. “(Carbon monoxide is) bright, and we have lots of facilities that can spot that.”
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into the detection process of molecular clouds, relevant to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: However, Eos eluded discovery despite being the closest molecular cloud to Earth because it does not contain much carbon monoxide, and therefore doesn’t emit the characteristic signature detected by conventional approaches, the researchers said. The key to unlocking this stunning find was searching for ultraviolet light emitted by hydrogen in the cloud.
annotations.reason: This explains why the cloud was previously undetected and how it was eventually discovered, crucial to the story.

annotations.paragraph: “The only reason we managed to catch it in this instance is because we’ve been able to look with a different color of light,” Haworth added.
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into the method used to discover the molecular cloud.

annotations.paragraph: Haworth and his colleagues detected Eos in data collected by a far-ultraviolet spectrograph called FIMS-SPEAR that operated as an instrument on a Korean satellite called STSAT-1.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the instrument and method used to detect the cloud.

annotations.paragraph: The data had just been released publicly in 2023 when lead study author Blakesley Burkhart, an associate professor in the department of physics and astronomy in the Rutgers School of Arts and Sciences, came across it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on how the data was accessed and who was involved in the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: The spectrograph breaks down far-ultraviolet light emitted by a material into its component wavelengths, similar to what a prism does with visible light, creating a spectrum that scientists can analyze.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the function of the spectrograph, which is relevant to understanding the discovery process.

annotations.paragraph: “This is the first-ever molecular cloud discovered by looking for far ultraviolet emission of molecular hydrogen directly,” Burkhart said in a news release. “The data showed glowing hydrogen molecules detected via fluorescence in the far ultraviolet. This cloud is literally glowing in the dark.”
annotations.reason: This quote highlights the significance of the discovery and the method used.

annotations.paragraph: These whirling lines in the sky are the trails of stars after an hour-long exposure above Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO), a Program of NSF NOIRLab. The trails are shortest around the North Star, Polaris, a star that happens to coincide almost directly with the celestial north pole. The different colors in the trails reflect the different temperatures of the stars, with blue being the hottest stars and yellow/red the coolest. The telescope visible above the horizon is the Nicholas U. Mayall 4-meter Telescope, and the red glow on the mountain is caused by red lights used to ensure the eyes of visitors and staff remain dark adapted at night. The yellow glow on the horizon comes from Tucson, AZ, about 89 kilometers (55 miles) to the northeast. Over the past decade, light pollution like this has increased by 2% a year from many medium-sized and larger cities. To help monitor light pollution in your city, you can participate in the citizen science campaign, Globe at Night.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the discovery of the molecular cloud and focuses on star trails and light pollution.

annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the discovery of the molecular cloud and discusses dark energy.

annotations.paragraph: The molecular cloud’s proximity to Earth provides a unique opportunity to study how solar systems form, Burkhart said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the significance of the molecular cloud's proximity to Earth.

annotations.paragraph: “Our discovery of Eos is exciting because we can now directly measure how molecular clouds are forming and dissociating, and how a galaxy begins to transform interstellar gas and dust into stars and planets,” Burkhart said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote about the importance of the discovery related to the molecular cloud.

annotations.paragraph: Astronomers thought they had a good handle on the locations and properties of the molecular clouds within about 1,600 light-years of the sun, making this “pretty cool discovery” quite a surprise, said Melissa McClure, an assistant professor at the University of Leiden in the Netherlands.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the significance of the discovery and includes a relevant quote.

annotations.paragraph: “This new molecular cloud, Eos, is only 300 light-years away, which is closer than any of the molecular clouds that we’ve known about previously,” McClure, who wasn’t involved in the research, said.
annotations.reason: Directly states the main fact about the discovery's proximity.

annotations.paragraph: “It’s puzzling why there’s something this big right in our solar neighborhood that we didn’t see before,” McClure added. “It would be a bit like living in a suburb with above-ground houses and open lots in it, and suddenly realizing that one of the open lots actually hosts a hidden underground bunker in it.”
annotations.reason: Provides an analogy to illustrate the unexpected nature of the discovery.
